statement:
If the [*coefficient ring*]{} $R$ is an integral domain, then so is also
its polynomial ring $R[X]$.

[*Proof.*]{} Let $f(X)$ and $g(X)$ be two non-zero polynomials in $R[X]$
and let $a_f$ and $b_g$ be their leading coefficients, respectively.
Thus $a_f \neq 0$, $b_g \neq 0$, and because $R$ has no zero divisors,
$a_fb_g \neq 0$. But the product $a_fb_g$ is the leading coefficient of
$f(X)g(X)$ and so $f(X)g(X)$ cannot be the zero polynomial.
Consequently, $R[X]$ has no zero divisors, Q.E.D.\
**Remark.** The theorem may by induction be generalized for the
polynomial ring $R[X_1,\,X_2,\,\ldots,\,X_n]$.
